geography.title: Geography
geography.description: Chad is a landlocked country in Central Africa, bordered by Libya to the north, Sudan to the east, the Central African Republic to the south, Cameroon and Nigeria to the southwest, and Niger to the west.

general: A bridge between the Maghreb and sub-Saharan Africa, a crossroads for trans-Saharan caravans and the cradle of nomadic civilizations, Chad embodies the contrasts between the northern desert and the southern savannah, between ascetic Muslim traditions and elaborate animist or Christian rituals, between nomadic populations living from their camels and pastures, and sedentary farmers shaping the land and giving it a human face.

Chad is a country in Central Africa covering 1,284,000 km¬≤, of which 560,000 km¬≤ are agricultural. Ranked 20th in the world by area, Chad is the fifth-largest country in Africa after Sudan, Algeria, the Democratic Republic of Congo, and Libya.
It is a vast country (twice the size of France), but landlocked and far from the sea. It is 1,700 km from Douala (Cameroon) and 2,400 km from Port Sudan on the Red Sea.

relief.title: Relief
items: The relief of Chad is basin-shaped, bordered by two mountain ranges and plateaus: to the north by the Tibesti massif (3,415 m at the Emi Koussi volcano) and to the east by the sandstone plateau of Ouadda√Ø (1,360 m) sloping towards the southwest. The lowest point is Lake Chad, a basin fed by the floodplains of the Chari and Logone rivers.

These two rivers form the only permanent hydrographic network: the Chari flows for 1,200 km from the Central African Republic, and the Logone, its main tributary, originates in Cameroon and flows for over 1,000 km. They meet near the capital. They are partially navigable four months a year. There are five main lakes: Chad, Fitri, Iro, L√©r√©, and Tekem.

climate.title: Climate and Vegetation
items: The south benefits from a humid tropical climate (Sudanian zone, the wettest and most populated), with wooded savannahs and sparse forests near villages due to excessive woodcutting. The central zone has a Sahelian climate with a thorny steppe and a longer dry season than the rainy season. The northern region, under a Saharan desert climate, covers half of the country with striking landscapes.

The harmattan, a dry and hot continental wind, blows from the east and northwest. The monsoon, equatorial, humid, and cool, comes from the southwest and marks the transition between the dry and rainy seasons.

Chad has 600,000 hectares of classified forests and 400,000 hectares of national parks. The two most important parks are Zakouma National Park in Salamat and Manda Park in the Sarh region, known for their biodiversity.

history.title: History
history.description: Chad's history dates back to antiquity with the Sahelian and Sudanese kingdoms.
content: Chad has a millennium-old history, marked by great Sahelian kingdoms.
French colonization profoundly transformed the country.
Independence was gained in 1960, followed by many political challenges.

cultural-text.item1: The first population census took place in 1993. It estimated the total population of Chad at 6,280,000 individuals, of whom 5.7% were nomads (in the strict sense), the rest being sedentary, semi-sedentary, or transhumant. The second census in Chad's history, the most recent one, was carried out more than fifteen years later, in 2009. Here are some key data from this count: the total population amounts to 11.03 million inhabitants (it is estimated at 12.8 million in 2016), of whom 50.6% are under 15 years old and 50.7% are women. The urban population is 22%, making Chad a predominantly rural country. This census highlights the very uneven geographical distribution of the population, with more than half concentrated in the southernmost 10% of the country. Thus, in Chad, there are enormous disparities in density, ranging from 52.4 inhab/km¬≤ in Western Logone to 0.1 inhab/km¬≤ in the Borkou, Ennedi, and Tibesti regions, where the population barely exceeds 300,000 individuals in the three regions combined; to note the extreme disparity between N'Djamena, with nearly 1 million inhabitants, and the Tibesti region, with 25,000 inhabitants!
cultural-text.item2: The most densely populated regions are Eastern Logone and Western Logone, Mayo Kebbi East and West, and Tandjil√©, all located in the southwest, and Ouadda√Ø (721,000 inhabitants) in the east of the country. The Chadian population is young (half are under 15), poorly educated (illiteracy rate of 65%, school enrollment rate of 75% in the South, compared to less than 8% in the North). They subsist thanks to agriculture (83% of the active population depends on the primary sector). Living conditions are precarious: 88.6% of homes are still built with traditional materials, 76.4% of inhabitants consume questionable water (puddle or undeveloped well); 79% of Chadians do not use latrines, 1% of households have access to electricity, and 99.5% only use wood or charcoal as a source of energy for cooking food.
cultural-text.item3: Moreover, Chad, due to its geographical location, is a true crossroads between the Arab world and the sub-Saharan world. The ancestral relations of trans-Saharan trade, the successive waves of migration of populations from the north and east, the rivalries that followed with the indigenous peoples, and the traditional slave raids have led these two worlds to rub shoulders and interbreed, in a mixture of colors and features, customs, and religions. Chad is therefore a true ethnic kaleidoscope. When in 1968 the project for a linguistic map of the Chad Atlas was presented to the Minister of National Education, he examined it for a long time before sighing: 'And to think that we have to make it a nation!'

ambassadeur.title: The Ambassador
ambassadeur.poste: Ambassador of Chad to C√¥te d'Ivoire
ambassadeur.bienvenue: Welcome to the Embassy of Chad in C√¥te d'Ivoire
ambassadeur.texte: The Republic of Chad, land of Touma√Ø, due to its strategic geographical position, occupies a prominent place in the heart of the African continent. The country, after a successful political transition of three years under the leadership of the Marshal of Chad, Mahamat Idriss DEBY ITNO, President of the Republic, Head of State, is taking giant steps for its economic takeoff. The political program of the Head of State is structured around twelve projects, each including several actions, notably peace, national security, and the promotion of a solidarity-based state. The development program entitled "Vision 2030, the Chad we want," based on the African Union's 2063 agenda and the United Nations' 2030 agenda, promulgated by the Heads of State of the African Union member states, is being implemented. This program, based on a pragmatic execution, aims to make Chad an emerging country by 2030. The Embassy of Chad in the Republic of C√¥te d'Ivoire has jurisdiction over four other countries, namely Ghana, Guinea, Sierra Leone, and Liberia. The main objectives of the mission are to maintain and strengthen diplomatic relations between Chad and these five countries. This all-out diplomacy embraces areas as varied as the economy, culture, and all that modern cooperation entails between peace-loving countries that share common interests. The mission of the High Representation of Chad in C√¥te d'Ivoire also consists of protecting the interests of its community in the five countries of its jurisdiction, in accordance with diplomatic practices. The platform offered to you is a unique and effective reference for obtaining general information about Chad, in order to effectively promote trade, investments, tourism, and culture. The entire Embassy team will always be at your disposal to offer you a warm welcome, not only to Chadians but to all those from other countries who wish to have essential information on the services we offer, including the issuance of visas and other administrative documents (consular card, birth certificate, marriage and death certificate). While waiting for a physical visit that we hope will be soon, welcome to "Virtual Chad."
ambassadeur.signature: His Excellency Mr. Gonfouli SOUARIBA, Ambassador of the Republic of Chad to the Republic of C√¥te d'Ivoire.
